Reproducer Testcase: https://oss-fuzz.com/download?testcase_id=4853171179225088

Issue filed automatically.

See https://google.github.io/oss-fuzz/advanced-topics/reproducing for instructions to reproduce this bug locally.

************************* UNREPRODUCIBLE *************************
Note: This crash might not be reproducible with the provided testcase. That said, for the past 14 days, we've been seeing this crash frequently.

It may be possible to reproduce by trying the following options:

comments.body:
Is this a failed "hg clone"?

I see this in the log:

Step #1: The command '/bin/sh -c hg clone https://bitbucket.org/jpommier/pffft $SRC/pffft' returned a non-zero code: 255
Finished Step #1
ERROR
ERROR: build step 1 "gcr.io/cloud-builders/docker" failed: step exited with non-zero status: 255

Oh, looks like the repo is not available on buildbucket anymore.

comments.author: mbonadei@chromium.org
comments.body: s/buildbucket/bitbucket

You are right, apparently bitbucket has pulled the plug on the mercurial repository. I’ll have to create a new one on github I guess.

—
Julien

Best regards,
Julien

Build type: fuzzing

To reproduce locally, please see: https://google.github.io/oss-fuzz/advanced-topics/reproducing#reproducing-build-failures

This bug tracker is not being monitored by OSS-Fuzz team. If you have any questions, please create an issue at https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/issues/new.

**This bug will be automatically closed within a day once it is fixed.**

comments.author: allenwebb@google.com
comments.body: This looks like an issue on the oss-fuzz side of things, but I will look into it if they don't resolve it.

comments.author: ClusterFuzz-External
comments.body:
Friendly reminder that the the build is still failing.
Please try to fix this failure to ensure that fuzzing remains productive.
Latest build log: https://oss-fuzz-build-logs.storage.googleapis.com/log-4ef8c257-1f43-4645-93e6-55ab2b4086d5.txt

comments.author: allenwebb@google.com
comments.body: I was able to reproduce the issue in the oss-fuzz environment. The fix is to add #include <unistd.h> to FDInputStream.hpp.

comments.author: allenwebb@google.com
comments.body:
Here is a pull request with the fix:
https://github.com/USBGuard/usbguard/pull/411

comments.author: ClusterFuzz-External
comments.body: The latest build has succeeded, closing this issue.

comments.author: a...@alexcrichton.com
comments.body:
Nick it looks like oss-fuzz pretty quickly found how wasmparser will reject valid modules due ot blowing limits. The bug here is that a function with hundreds of return types is created, but that's rejected due to blowing the limits. 

Do you think it would make sense to add support to wasm-smith to limit input automatically? Or a configuration option to limit the maximum number of parameters and return types?

comments.author: a...@alexcrichton.com
comments.body: Er nevermind, looks like you're already way ahead of me, this is just a bug. I think this should be fixed by https://github.com/fitzgen/wasm-smith/pull/7

comments.author: fitz...@gmail.com
comments.body: We are trying to create a very big table, and we OOM.

comments.author: fitz...@gmail.com
comments.body: The global allocator that ASan installs doesn't seem to ever return `null` and let malloc fail. Instead it crashes the process. This means that even if we write code to recover from malloc failure, we can't get this fuzz bug passing :-/

comments.author: a...@alexcrichton.com
comments.body:
This bug is effectively exposing inefficiency in the `wast` text parser that we're using. The 1MB input translates to a 27MB text file which we're parsing. It's a bit egregious, still, that we're allocating 2GB of memory to parser a 27MB text file.

I've started work on this in https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/98, but further commits will be needed to bring it below the 2GB limit.

comments.author: a...@alexcrichton.com
comments.body: Some more savings in https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/99

comments.author: marte...@gmail.com
comments.body:
Unfortunately, this is an artifact of the fuzz setup :(
What's happening here is that we're replacing the EncryptedExtensions message with a NewSessionTicket message (at the correct encryption level: 1-RTT). At this point, the handshake hasn't completed yet, so the client would wait for that.
This can never happen in practice: As the handshake is not yet complete, we wouldn't even be able to open a 1-RTT packet.

The fix for the fuzz-test is straightforward: Check if the corresponding AEAD opener is available before injecting a message at a given encryption level.

comments.author: marte...@gmail.com
comments.body: Should be fixed by https://github.com/lucas-clemente/quic-go/pull/2739.

comments.author: marte...@gmail.com
comments.body:
This is a bug in the fuzz setup, not a bug in quic-go.
What's happening here is the following: The client receives an EncryptedExtensions message that contains an invalid QUIC Transport Parameter extension as well as an invalid ALPN. The TLS stack therefore sends a TLS alert, while the QUIC stack at the same time throws a TRANSPORT_PARAMETER error.

As the TLS handshake is running in its own Go routine, which of these errors occurs first is undefined, and the QUIC specification doesn't require any order here. The important thing here is that only the first of these errors should be processed (in the case of a QUIC connection, it would be sent out in a CONNECTION_CLOSE frame). The fuzz setup should reflect this.

comments.author: marte...@gmail.com
comments.body: Will be fixed by https://github.com/lucas-clemente/quic-go/pull/2740.

comments.author: marte...@gmail.com
comments.body:
This is a bug in qtls: The client sent the server a valid ClientHello, but offered a TLS version != TLS 1.3.
The server needs to close the connection in this case.

Should be fixed by https://github.com/lucas-clemente/quic-go/pull/2773.

comments.author: bugdroid
comments.body:
The following revision refers to this bug:
  https://skia.googlesource.com/skia/+/5eea6aea02d97df1c7c18ee89664f5e1a082801d

commit 5eea6aea02d97df1c7c18ee89664f5e1a082801d
Author: Brian Osman <brianosman@google.com>
Date: Wed Sep 09 21:07:32 2020

SkSL: Fail harder when trying to return a value from a void function

This prevents the inliner from getting really confused when the result
variable is null, but a return statement appears and tries to use it.

Bug: oss-fuzz:25525
Change-Id: Ief85990f707e68e104931a9778ffab35a27acfb1
Reviewed-on: https://skia-review.googlesource.com/c/skia/+/315963
Commit-Queue: Brian Osman <brianosman@google.com>
Reviewed-by: John Stiles <johnstiles@google.com>

[modify] https://crrev.com/5eea6aea02d97df1c7c18ee89664f5e1a082801d/src/sksl/SkSLIRGenerator.cpp

comments.body:
The following revision refers to this bug:
  https://skia.googlesource.com/skia/+/01a3eb44afe5b1a0a5b12d34de8908e860696141

commit 01a3eb44afe5b1a0a5b12d34de8908e860696141
Author: Brian Osman <brianosman@google.com>
Date: Mon Sep 14 18:42:57 2020

SkSL: When simplifcation requires a rescan, do it right away

Fixes a use-after-free where switch statements were replaced by the
statically-determined case, but there were other (later) blocks in the
list that still had pointers into the no-longer-valid cases.

Bug: oss-fuzz:25554
Change-Id: I23b80d66d49a251b59ce02d74f31996858c04395
Reviewed-on: https://skia-review.googlesource.com/c/skia/+/316876
Reviewed-by: Ethan Nicholas <ethannicholas@google.com>
Commit-Queue: Brian Osman <brianosman@google.com>

[modify] https://crrev.com/01a3eb44afe5b1a0a5b12d34de8908e860696141/src/sksl/SkSLCompiler.cpp

comments.author: marte...@gmail.com
comments.body:
Will be fixed by https://github.com/lucas-clemente/quic-go/pull/2777.

When receiving a handshake message after another handshake messages that doesn't cause any action from the TLS stack (i.e. Certificate and CertificateVerify), the handshake would run into a deadlock if the first of these handshake messages caused an error in the TLS stack.

We need to make sure that we wait until a message has been fully processed before proceeding with the handshake.

comments.author: cmeis...@gmail.com
comments.body:
Looks like after an hour it stops?

:~/code/github/cmeister2/oss-fuzz$  python infra/helper.py coverage --port 8009 libsndfile 2>&1 | ts
Sep 16 14:09:36 Running sndfile_fuzzer
Sep 16 15:09:36 Error occured while running sndfile_fuzzer:
Sep 16 15:09:36 INFO: Seed: 4206533063
Sep 16 15:09:36 INFO: Loaded 1 modules   (20 inline 8-bit counters): 20 [0x7be955, 0x7be969),
Sep 16 15:09:36 INFO: Loaded 1 PC tables (20 PCs): 20 [0x552f30,0x553070),
Sep 16 15:09:36 MERGE-OUTER: 15663 files, 0 in the initial corpus, 0 processed earlier
Sep 16 15:09:36 MERGE-OUTER: attempt 1
Sep 16 15:09:36 ==27== libFuzzer: run interrupted; exiting
Sep 16 15:09:36 ==27== libFuzzer: run interrupted; exiting
Sep 16 15:09:36 du: cannot access '/out/dumps/sndfile_fuzzer.*.profraw': No such file or directory
Sep 16 15:09:36 error: /out/dumps/*.profdata: No such file or directory
Sep 16 15:09:36 Downloading corpora for libsndfile project to /home/md3/code/github/cmeister2/oss-fuzz/build/corpus/libsndfile
Sep 16 15:09:36 Running: docker run --rm --privileged -i -e FUZZING_ENGINE=libfuzzer -e FUZZING_LANGUAGE=c -e PROJECT=libsndfile -e SANITIZER=coverage -e HTTP_PORT=8009 -e COVERAGE_EXTRA_ARGS= -p 8009:8009 -v /home/md3/code/github/cmeister2/oss-fuzz/build/corpus/libsndfile:/corpus -v /home/md3/code/github/cmeister2/oss-fuzz/build/out/libsndfile:/out -t gcr.io/oss-fuzz-base/base-runner coverage
Sep 16 15:09:36 Failed to generate clang code coverage report.

I've honestly never seen this issue before.

Build type: fuzzing

**This bug will be automatically closed within a day once it is fixed.**

comments.author: wi...@1wt.eu
comments.body: It looks like there are some sed commands applied the Makefile, I don't see why, given that apparently they're just here to replace variables. Here the problem definitely is caused by sed not matching CC=gcc since it was turned to cc very recently, but the right solution would be to completely drop sed and pass CC=clang LD=clang++ CPU_CFLAGS="$ORIG_CFLAGS" and that should be OK I guess, from what I can see in the error output.

comments.author: da...@adalogics.com
comments.body:
Ah perfect, from looking at the updates to the Makefile it seems we can drop the SED commands and simply use environment variables - that's great! 

I am quite busy during the day today but I will see if I can fix it up this evening.

comments.author: wi...@1wt.eu
comments.body:
Note just to be sure, I'm not speaking about environment variables but about make arguments. You should build using:

    make TARGET=generic CC=clang LD=clang++ CPU_CFLAGS="$ORIG_CFLAGS"

(more or less what you possibly needed to adjust, of course). No pb for your availability, don't worry :-)

comments.author: da...@adalogics.com
comments.body: Ah right, thanks for the clarification - this will make the build script much nicer too.

comments.author: da...@adalogics.com
comments.body:
I get passed the error by removing the sed commands and then running make with the string: make TARGET=generic CC=${CC} LD=${CXX} CPU_CFLAGS="${ORIG_CFLAGS}"

However, now I get the issues:
src/sock_inet.c:296:70: error: use of undeclared identifier 'errno'
                        memprintf(errmsg, "cannot create receiving socket (%s)", strerror(errno));
                                                                                          ^
src/sock_inet.c:350:70: error: use of undeclared identifier 'errno'
                        memprintf(errmsg, "cannot bind receiver to device (%s)", strerror(errno));
                                                                                          ^
src/sock_inet.c:372:57: error: use of undeclared identifier 'errno'
                memprintf(errmsg, "cannot bind socket (%s)", strerror(errno));


I think this is introduced in a recent commit https://github.com/haproxy/haproxy/commit/3cd58bf80555fd22687a11672d5c0dd4c11c2089

comments.author: wi...@1wt.eu
comments.body: Ah sorry about that David, now fixed! I was careful about it only on half of the changes and this one slipped through.

comments.author: da...@adalogics.com
comments.body: Perfect - it works now and the PR is here: https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/pull/4454

comments.author: wi...@1wt.eu
comments.body: Great, thanks David!

comments.body: The latest build has succeeded, closing this issue.

summary: Unwanted automated comments regarding change in Cc
author: welln...@aevum.de
description:
What steps will reproduce the problem?
(1) Subscribe to issue https://bugs.chromium.org/p/oss-fuzz/issues/detail?id=21218
(2) Wait
(3) Receive daily notifications about updated Cc

What is the expected output?

No notification spam.

What do you see instead?

Daily notifications about updated CC.

comments.author: zhangtiff@chromium.org
comments.body:
The daily notifications here seem to be the result of an automated tool ( https://bugs.chromium.org/u/382749006/ ) that's adding comments automatically to the issue. 

To avoid this spam, I'd consider reaching out to the owners of the tool to ask about whether the amount of commenting by the bot can be reduced somehow. 

On the Monorail side, I could see two possible features that could be implemented to help with this: 

- The ability for the user to not receive emails for bot comments. 
- The ability for users to subscribe only to comments that contains comment text, not just metadata updates. (Maybe an exception for CC changes to the user specifically)

comments.author: zhangtiff@google.com
comments.body: Moved issue monorail:8363 to now be issue oss-fuzz:25870.

comments.author: zhangtiff@google.com
comments.body: Moved this issue to oss-fuzz project, to better triage the issue with ClusterFuzz-External being noisy.

comments.author: welln...@aevum.de
comments.body:
From a quick look, the CCs are updated by ClusterFuzz here:

https://github.com/google/clusterfuzz/blob/master/src/appengine/handlers/cron/oss_fuzz_apply_ccs.py

According to the Monorail user page, email to the offending address bounces. My guess is that Monorail automatically removes such addresses from the CC list which causes ClusterFuzz to readd it over and over again.

comments.author: deadbeef@chromium.org
comments.body:
The error is:
/src/usrsctp/usrsctplib/user_environment.c:49:10: fatal error: 'sys/random.h' file not found

This is from switching from weinrank's fork to their main repository; I'll make another pull request to change it back.

This isn't the only issue with <sys/random.h>, though. I discovered today that when targeting android versions less than 28, getrandom is not present. So we need to do some detection of <sys/random.h> capabilities in the build files either way.

Note: This crash might not be reproducible with the provided testcase. That said, for the past 14 days, we've been seeing this crash frequently.

It may be possible to reproduce by trying the following options:
- Run testcase multiple times for a longer duration.
- Run fuzzing without testcase argument to hit the same crash signature.

If it still does not reproduce, try a speculative fix based on the crash stacktrace and verify if it works by looking at the crash statistics in the report. We will auto-close the bug if the crash is not seen for 14 days.
